title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to submit a debt report to Congress, including historical levels of debt, current amount, composition, and future projections. This is mandated by the "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015." The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on various aspects related to the national debt, such as income taxes as a percentage of GDP, future debt drivers, meeting debt obligations, and reduction measures if the debt limit is not raised. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on various aspects related to the national debt, including notifying Congress when the debt limit is reached and when measures are being taken to address it, as well as recommending a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on aspects related to the national debt, including proposals by the President to reduce debt in the short, medium, and long term, and the impact of an increased debt limit. The President plans to adjust the debt-to-GDP ratio and assess the impact of increasing the debt limit on future government spending, debt service, and the position of the US dollar as the international reserve currency. Projections of fiscal health and sustainability of major entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid will also be considered. The President plans to publicly disclose reduction measures used to avoid defaulting on government obligations when the debt limit is reached. The reduction measures used to avoid default will be disclosed, including total dollar amounts used and estimated amounts still available. The Secretary will provide the date when all measures will be exhausted. The Secretary will disclose reduction measures used to avoid default, total dollar amounts used, estimated amounts available, date of exhaustion, extraordinary measures to fund obligations if debt limit not raised, projection of how long measures will fund government, projection of administrative cost, and acknowledgment of technological capability to pay only principal. The Administration's technological capability to pay only principal and interest on the national debt in the event of reaching the debt limit is questioned. A progress report on implementing the President's proposals is required, with exceptions noted. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide a debt report to the public for at least 6 months, including a detailed explanation, with exceptions for multiple appearances by a Secretary during a President's term. The Secretary of the Treasury must release relevant information including debt reports, detailed explanations, progress reports, and other necessary information for public understanding of the statutory debt limit and Government debt. Reduction measures are defined as specific actions outlined in the section. Reduction measures defined in this section include directing debt issuance by the Federal Financing Bank, suspending investments in the Government Securities Investment Fund, and suspending investments in the stabilization fund. The Secretary may implement various measures, including suspending investments in certain funds, selling assets before maturity, and taking other appropriate actions. The Secretary may implement measures such as suspending investments in funds, selling assets early, and taking other appropriate actions, including those related to the Disability Fund or the Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund before maturity. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the table of analysis for chapter 31 of title 31, United States Code. The House of Representatives passed a report on reaching the debt limit on February 11, 2016, attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
